Investments under the component are intended to maintain

Project Name: Improving Livelihoods and Nutrition for Smallholder Agro-Pastoralists in Sudan
Project Development Objective: The proposed Project Development Objective (PDO) is to improve knowledge of nutritional diet and increase access to nutritious food in select communities.
Implementing Agency: Ministry of Animal Resources

Project Name: Transforming the Mekong Delta GCF Program for Vietnam
Project Development Objective: The project development objective (PDO) is to scale up the transition of small-holder farmers to climate resilient livelihoods and strengthen their participation in flood-based value chains in select areas of the upper Mekong Delta in Vietnam. This Project is part of the overall Mekong Program for Vietnam and Cambodia.
Implementing Agency: Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (MARD)
Abstract: The proposed Project represents an important contribution to the implementation of the recent Prime Minister’s Resolution 120 onSustainable Development of the Mekong Delta. Specifically, the proposed Project aims to address the issues of regionalcoordination, sustainable financing and international cooperation in the Mekong Delta, as well as finance the interprovincialinvestments which respond to some urgent needs identified and support the large-scale transformation envisioned in the Resolution.This proposed project seeks to enhance a spatially integrated approach across the Mekong Delta in Vietnam to increase climateresilience, identify innovative investments in nature-based solutions, that contribute to the paradigm shift in delta developmentthat adapts to climate risks; and support regional coordination and sustainable financing efforts in Vietnam. The proposed Projectwould complement the on-going IDA project on Integrated Climate Resilience and Sustainable Livelihoods (MD-ICRSL) --- following thesame transformative and integrated approach. The proposed Project focuses on the upper delta provinces of Vietnam’s Mekong Delta.The provinces within the Plain of Reeds (PoR) and Long Xuyen Quadrangle (LXQ) have undertaken visioning exercises and reached widepolitical consensus to transition out of three-rice towards more nature-based solutions of flood-based agriculture which helpmitigate extreme floods and droughts. Such interprovincial investments are expected to provide efficient and cost-effectivesolutions that work to adapt to natural conditions of the floodplain, rather than invest in expensive structural measures thatmaintain business as usual. The Project includes three components –the first, supporting the implementation of policies relatedto PM Resolution 120; the second, providing critical financing for feasibility studies and other analyses to prepareinterprovincial projects, as well as for small-scale infrastructure to enable farmers/ communities to effectively transitionlivelihoods for greater climate resilience; and the last, project management and monitoring.Component 1: Policy ImplementationSupport for PM Resolution 120 Sub-component 1.1: Supporting Inter-Provincial and Regional Coordination Sub-component 1.2:Supporting Financing Mechanism for the Mekong Delta Sub-component 1.3: Improving Enabling Environment for Private Sector Financingand Entrepreneurship Sub-component 1.4: Enhancing Climate Information Services and Transboundary Collaboration in the MekongDeltaComponent 2: Scaling up Climate Resilience for Interprovincial ProjectsSub-component 2.1: Investing in Natural Capital inthe Plain of Reeds Sub-component 2.2: Securing Long-Term Sustainability in Long Xuyen QuadrangleSubcomponent 2.3: PilotingInnovation in Riverbank Erosion Management. Component 3: Project Management and Monitoring

Project Name: Promoting Social Accountability in the Governance of Armenian Water Resources
Project Development Objective: The project development objective is to promote, on a pilot basis, local climate action by strengthening community-level partnerships for improved water resource management practices in target communities.
Implementing Agency: Urban Foundation for Sustainable Development (UFSD),Hetq Investigative Journalists NGO (HIJ)
Abstract: The project responds to the Armenia CPF focus area on sustainable management of environmental and natural resources, and consistsof three components:Component 1: Capacity building for collaborative social accountability. This component focuses on providingcapacity development of active groups of water users – members of WUAs to hold WUA management accountable for their activities andfair distribution of irrigation water. Activities under this component follow ‘learning by doing’ principle. They will beimplemented parallel to those under Component (ii) and may coincide or interplay with them to promote multi-stakeholderpartnership.Component 2: Implementing collaborative social accountability mechanisms for improved water resource governanceefforts. This component focuses on providing training to WUAs to strengthen participatory management, become more transparent andaccountable before water users and public in general. Activities under this component will be implemented parallel to those underComponent (1) and may coincide or interplay with them to promote multi-stakeholder partnership.Component 3: Improving knowledgeand learning on social accountability in the Armenian water resources sector, and project management. This component focused onknowledge sharing about project’s achievements, multi-stakeholder partnership is established aiming at improving socialaccountability in water sector of Armenia.

Project Name: Viet Nam TCAF Project
Implementing Agency: MARD

Project Name: Sustainable Mercury Management in Nonferrous Metal Industry
Project Development Objective: The Project Development Objective is to strengthen the regulatory framework and capacity for reducing mercury emission, and to promote the adoption of related techniques and good practices for enterprises in the nonferrous metal industry.
Implementing Agency: Foreign Environmental Cooperation Office of Ministry of Ecology and Environment
Borrower: The Ministry of Finance of the People's Republic of China (For and on Behalf of the People's Republic of China)
Abstract: The Project Development Objective (PDO) is to strengthen the regulatory framework and capacity for reducing mercury emission, and to promote the adoption of related techniques and good practices for enterprises in the nonferrous metal industry.PDO-Level Indicators • National level Standards, technical guidelines, and national replication plan submitted or adopted to support mercury reduction and recovery in the sector (number)• BAT/BEP successfully demonstrated for selected enterprises (number; each enterprise can demonstration more than one BAT/BEP)• Mercury reduction by demonstration enterprise (metric tons/year)• Direct project beneficiaries (number, and gender disaggregated).Component 1. Strengthen Regulatory Framework, Knowledge Dissemination, and Promotion of Sector wide Replication (total cost US$32.2 million, of which GEF US$7.3 million)This component will finance technical assistance activities to promote industry-wide replication and ensure the long-term sustainability of mercury reduction in the nonferrous metal sector. Among other things, activities supported will include development and update of four national mandatory standards for emissions and product specifications based on the experience of the demonstration enterprises and the other enterprises in the whole industry, three of which are expected to be adopted within the project duration while one will be submitted for adoption and may be approved after project closing due to the longer time needed for the processes. The technical assistance and studies under Component 1 will provide guidance to the demonstration activities under component 2 while the lessons learned under component 2 will in turn inform the regulatory improvement under component 1, which forms a feedback loop. The regulatory and TA component will also pave the way for these technologies and practices to be validated and certified as BAT/BEP for the national catalogue and potentially inform the international BAT/BEP to be recommended for the Minamata Convention. Component 2. Demonstration of Mercury Emission Control and Recovery Technology (total cost US$120 million, of which GEF US$12 million)This component will demonstrate technologies and practices for mercury control, abatement, and recovery at selected participating enterprises. It will provide technical assistance and investment financing (goods and civil works) to four enterprises, supporting at least one production line in each of the four areas: mercury recovery; specialized mercury abatement; synergistic control for conventional pollutants and mercury; and online monitoring equipment for gaseous mercury., which are representative of the priority technologies. This component is expected to be implemented through subgrant agreements with enterprises selected during project preparation and early project implementation to allow more time for careful selections and phased approach. The Yuguang Zinc Industry Co., Ltd. in Henan province has been identified through a nationwide call for proposals that was open to all enterprises, state-owned and private, based on pre-agreed selection criteria to demonstrate mercury recovery technology. These criteria evaluate viability of the proposed technologies, enterprise’s commitment to the project, facility’s compliance status with applicable environmental and social requirements and its financial performance and level of committed co-financing. Three more demonstration enterprises will be selected during the early years of implementation, preferably from the provinces of Henan, Hunan, Shaanxi, Shandong, and Guizhou province, as well as the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, where top lead, zinc, and copper production capacity is concentrated.Regular evaluation and verification of the effectiveness of demonstration activities will be carried out during project implementation with data shared with the environmental authorities, and the verified demonstration technologies are expected to be recommended for inclusion in the BAT/BEP guidelines, which will greatly facilitate their replication nationwide. Component 3. Project Management (total cost US$8.1 million, of which GEF US$1 million)This component will support (a) day-to-day project management, coordination, planning, administration, and supervision of project implementation; (b) technical support, including the preparation of terms of reference and procurement management; (c) monitoring, reporting, and evaluation, E&S monitoring, including submitting semiannual and annual reports of project progress, E&S reports, and a project completion report; and (d) project fund management and disbursement management.

Project Name: EnABLE Costa Rica Country Project Supporting Social Inclusion in FCPF Emission Reductions Program
Project Development Objective: The Project Development Objectives (PDOs) is to enhance the inclusion of Indigenous Peoples and targeted beneficiaries in Costa Rica’s ERP and maximize their use of carbon and non-carbon benefits.
Implementing Agency: FUNBAM
Abstract: The Project will aim to enhance the inclusion of Indigenous Peoples and targeted beneficiaries in Costa Rica’s ERP and maximize their use of carbon and non-carbon benefits. Project beneficiaries will consist of IPs of the 24 indigenous territories who could benefit from the ERP, its BSP, and other REDD+ activities in the future. Project consists of the following 3 components:(1) Component 1 will support (a) capacity building for development and implementation of community investments (subprojects or SPs), including designs, studies, market analyses, etc; and (b) the preparation and implementation of such SPs. Elegible SPs will aim at: restoring land, generating ecosystem services, or improving income of IP communities through sustainable economic activities; increasing the profitability of alternative economic activities that contribute to the reduction of GHG emissions; supporting land tenure security; and/or supporting mitigation of and adaptation to climate change in forest ecosystems, promoting the resilience of territories. Anticipated activities include: (i) capacity building: training courses and extension services to enhance sustainable livelihoods; (ii) purcharse of inputs: seeds, equipment, etc., (iii) technical assistance: consultancies; and (iv) construction of small scale infrastructure. Small infrastructure refers to essential, small-scale facilities and services that form the foundation for a community's daily operations, promoting sustainable economic activities, social interactions, and enhancing the overall quality of life. Examples include: community water systems, construction of visitor centers or other small tourism infrastructure to promote ecotourism, construction of small graneries, storage facilities or sheds for agroforestry production or other non-timber products, among others . Potential SPs will be screened against an exhaustive and detailed Exclusion List of ineligible activities. This component will also finance a Lead Beneficiary Entity (LBE) for each of the four territorial regional blocks of intervention, to lead and coordinate the management of community investments on behalf of the beneficiary IP organizations, including support on E&S aspects.(2) Component 2 will finance activities that strengthen the voice and participation of IPs in climate-related decision-making bodies. It includes the operationalization of a permanent platform for IPs representatives to meet, set priorities, and engage in climate-related decision-making bodies, as well as training programs for cultural mediators and IP representatives who can bridge the gap between government protocols and Indigenous customs. (3) Component 3 will finance operating costs of the Project Administration Agency (PAA) namely, the Environmental Bank Foundation (Fundacion Banco Ambiental, or FUNBAM). FUNBAM will be tasked with, among others, environmental and social responsibilities.

Project Name: Sustainable Management of Ecosystems in Miombo Ecoregions of Zambia
Project Development Objective: To strengthen the climate resilience of communities and ecosystems in the Miombo region, through improved management and restoration.
Implementing Agency: Ministry of Green Economy and Environment
Borrower: Ministry of Finance and National Planning,Republic of Zambia
Abstract: Zambia has approximately 45.9 million hectares of forest, representing approximately 66% of its total land mass. In the entire Miombo eco-region, Zambia has the highest diversity of trees and is the centre for endemism for Brachystegia tree species - one of the Miombo woodland’s key species. The miombo woodlands in Zambia are a vast and diverse ecosystem that covers approximately two-thirds of the country's land area. Socioeconomically, miombo woodlands are a vital source of livelihood for rural communities who depend on them for firewood, charcoal, timber, and non-timber forest products such as mushrooms, honey, and medicinal plants. Overall, the forest sector is important to the Zambian economy, essentially because most people depend on the use of natural resources for their survival. Forests are estimated to employ 1.4 million people, and 60% of rural households heavily depend upon the use of natural resources. In addition, miombo woodlands provide grazing lands for livestock and support ecotourism activities such as birdwatching, hiking, and wildlife viewing. Forests provide 80% of the energy needs in the form of firewood and charcoal. They contribute about 4.7% of GDP to the national economy or $957.5 million annually to about 6.3% ($1277 million) when multiplier effects of forest and tourism-related activities on other sectors are considered. However, the miombo woodlands are under pressure due to large-scale clearing of land for commercial agriculture, settlements and infrastructure development, livestock grazing and generally land use change. Also, in places with high population, traditional practices such as slash-and-burn agriculture and livestock grazing are having a negative impact on forests. These practices are leading to deforestation, soil degradation, and loss of biodiversity. Finally, climate change is having an impact on the miombo woodlands, with changes in temperature and rainfall patterns affecting the growth and distribution of tree species. Environmentally, miombo woodlands play a crucial role in maintaining the ecological balance - they help to regulate the water cycle by capturing and storing rainfall, which supports both terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems. Miombo woodlands also act as carbon sinks, sequestering carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and mitigating the effects of climate change. Furthermore, miombo woodlands are home to a diverse range of flora and fauna, including endemic and threatened species such as the African elephant, African wild dog, and sable antelope. Protecting miombo woodlands and their biodiversity is therefore, essential for the conservation of Zambia's natural heritage, socioeconomic benefits and multiple global environmental benefits.This project will build on lessons from the Transforming Landscapes for Resilience and Development (TRALARD) Project (P164764) ($87.2 million 2019 – 2025 in Luapula, Northern and Muchinga provinces). With a focus on promoting diversified, resilient, sustainable livelihoods and management of community forests and protected areas, TRALARD seeks to improve natural resource management in select districts to support sustainable livelihoods. SMEMZ will be strategically designed to i) catalyze the investments; and ii) scale-up best practices related to transformational approaches to integrated natural resource management from TRALARD while supporting livelihoods of local communities. To catalyze the investments and support scaling up, SMEMZ is proposed to be implemented in Muchinga, Copperbelt and Central provinces which are located in the miombo woodland ecoregion. The Sustainable Management of Ecosystems in Miombo Ecoregions of Zambia (SMEMZ) project is conceived to restore degraded production landscapes, enhance biodiversity conservation, and increase the adaptative capacity of the vulnerable population to cope with climate risks within the Zambian miombo ecoregion using an integrated natural resources management approach. The main objective of the proposed project is to strengthen the climate resilience of the miombo forest and forest-dependent communities in the Copperbelt, Central and Muchinga Provinces of Zambia. This will be achieved through the integration of adaptation considerations in land use planning, implementation of sustainable management practices and the promotion of community-based adaptation. The project includes three interrelated components: i) strengthening the policy and institutional environment for, land rehabilitation, biodiversity conservation and climate change adaptation in the Kabwe District; ii) promoting an integrated landscape approach in support of sustainable ecosystem management practices and biodiversity conservation in the project area; iii) enhancing climate change adaptation through community-based natural resource management; and iv) knowledge management.

Project Name: Regenerative Agriculture for Agro-Pastoral Livelihoods in Ethiopia
Project Development Objective: Improving livelihoods and climate resilience of Agro-pastoralists through regenerative agriculture practices in the Lowlands of Ethiopia.
Implementing Agency: Sasakawa Africa Association (SAA)
Abstract: The project's overarching objective is to enhance Agro-pastoralist (AP) communities' livelihoods and climate resilience in the target regions by promoting regenerative agriculture practices in crop and livestock production, strengthening the extension system, improving agribusiness skills, and creating new or better employment opportunities for youth, women, and marginalized groups along the agriculture and livestock value chains.The specific objectives include:Promote Sustainable Agricultural Practices by introducing regenerative farming techniques such as crop rotation, cover cropping, land management strategies, agroforestry, and crop-livestock integration. These practices aim to build soil fertility, reduce reliance on external inputs, improve biodiversity conservation, and enhance ecosystem resilience.Enhance Livelihoods, Household Nutrition, and Income by equipping Agro-pastoralists with the knowledge and skills needed to diversify their agricultural activities, reduce post-harvest losses, foster increased income opportunities through the incorporation of value-added products and alternative crops, and increase nutrition literacy.Empower Agro-pastoral Communities and enhance their capacity through skill development training and decision-making in regenerative farming, nutrition, marketing, and agribusiness.Transitioning to more regenerative agriculture practices enables Agro-pastoralist households to improve soil fertility and health, amplify agrobiodiversity, and produce diversified, nutritious food. This transition would allow them to increase agricultural productivity, improve diets, adapt to climate change, absorb and recover from shocks, and build sustainable climate resilience.The project will include three components: (1) Promoting regenerative agriculture; (2) Institutional and Human Capacity Building; and (3) Project Management, Monitoring & Evaluation, and Knowledge Management.

Project Name: Philippines Community Resilience Project - Pagkilos
Project Development Objective: The objective of the Project is to strengthen community capacities for participatory resilience planning and increase access to resilient investments in vulnerable areas.
Implementing Agency: Department of Social Welfare and Development
Abstract: Pagkilos is a community resilience project which aims to strengthen resilience in vulnerable and poor areas. The project targets 500 vulnerable municipalities in rural areas selected based on high poverty incidence, high level of exposure to natural and climate hazards, presence of indigenous people and high rates of malnutrition. The Project will target and ensure inclusion of vulnerable populations at-risk from impacts from natural hazards and climate change, including 4P beneficiaries, Indigenous People and women, and will be implemented over a five-year period. The Project will have four components: (i) Community Resilience: Strengthening risk informed planning through a participatory locally-led process and financing resilience investments, including rehabilitation or construction of small resilience infrastructure (green and grey) and livelihood infrastructure and practices; (ii) Institutional Support for Local Resilience: Support for capacity building of project staff and partner agencies for enhanced local risk-informed planning; and a resilience knowledge platform to put in place risk resilience planning resources and tools for communities as well as barangay and municipal local government units; (iii) Project Monitoring, Evaluation and Management; and (iv) a Contingent Emergency Response Component. The Project will be implemented and managed by the Department of Social Welfare and Development (DSWD) through the existing Kalahi community platform, which delivers through locally-led development. The Kalahi platform has through the last 20 years accumulated invaluable capacity for service delivery at the local level and this mechanism, with a proven track record for delivery and results, is therefore well placed to support the critical and urgent agenda on local resilience. The DSWD, who will lead the coordination and oversight of project implementation, has as its core mandate to support community resilience. DSWD will be supported by the Department of Interior and Local Government, which has a mandate for government planning and National Commission for Indigenous People.

Project Name: Agroecology and Sustainable Rural Development in Pernambuco
Project Development Objective: The proposed Project Development Objective (PDOs) is to increase the adoption of agroecological and sustainable environmental practices by targeted family farmers and regions in the State of Pernambuco and, in case of an Eligible Crisis or Emergency, to respond promptly and effectively to it.
Implementing Agency: IPA - Agronomic Institute of Pernambuco
Abstract: Component 1 – Strengthening Agroecological Family Farming (total estimated cost: US$ 39.47 million; US$ 33.67 million IBRD financing, and US$ 5.8 million counterpart financing). This component will finance: (i) the integration of family farmers, their families and their organizations into value chains and improving their access to markets; and (ii) the dissemination and adoption of agroecological production by beneficiary family farmers, their families and organizations, including strengthening their environmental management and preservation. All financing under this component will support agroecological activities, aiming to strengthen the climate resilience of the beneficiaries through climate change mitigation and adaptation strategies, and towards low-carbon development. Component 1 is linked to Pillar 1 of the MPA as it finances direct support to family farmers to overcome market failures, helping them to adopt new technologies and farming practices. Subcomponent 1.1: Supporting the Implementation of PFSPAs (total estimated cost: US$ 29.81 million; US$ 25.43 million IBRD financing, and US$ 4.38 million counterpart financing). This subcomponent will finance activities included under the PFSPAs for Community Associations (CAs). The implementation of the PFSPAs will support the agroecological transition of family farmers in the region, thus enhancing the adaptation of productive systems to climate change and increasing availability of quality foods that could improve the nutrition status of the beneficiaries. The PMU will oversee the implementation support to the PFSPAs. CAs will submit their PFSPAs for approval, ensuring ownership. This subcomponent will use a demand-driven participatory approach to inform the CAs of the options available regarding agroecological technologies and practices that the CA can then include in their PFSPA. The options of agroecological technologies and practices will be outlined in the POM. This support will contribute to the Private Capital Enabling (PCE) strategy, with an estimated contribution of US$500 thousand. As the inclusion of agroecological practices and technologies in the PFSPAs proposals is an eligibility criterion , all financing under this subcomponent will contribute to climate-resilient and low carbon development outcomes . Every PFSPA under this subcomponent will also include a set of activities for the enhancement of sustainable use of natural resources (including water, soil and biodiversity) by the family farms served. The selection of PFSPAs will prioritize youth, quilombolas, Indigenous People, and traditional communities by offering them differentiated scores and specific calls for proposals for each group. Women will also be offered targeted calls.Subcomponent 1.2 – Supporting the Implementation of Business Plans (BPs) (total estimated cost US$ 1.28 million; US$ 1.09 million IBRD financing, and US$ 190 thousand counterpart financing). This subcomponent will finance the activities included under the BPs of Producer Organizations (POs). Under this subcomponent, the POs will prepare their BPs, which will outline their overall business objective, marketing and growth strategy, and required investments. The type of investments in the BPs to be financed under this subcomponent may include (among other aspects): (i) physical infrastructure (such as processing, storage, and warehouses) , , (ii) marketing and promotion efforts, (iii) purchasing of equipment, and (iv) technical support, advisory services, and training for the successful implementation of the BP . POs will submit their BPs for approval, ensuring ownership and committing to implement counterpart-financed activities. These BPs will be assessed and approved by the Evaluation Committee. This subcomponent will use a demand-driven participatory approach to inform the POs of the options available regarding agroecological technologies and practices that the PO can then include in their BP. This subcomponent will contribute to the Private Capital Enabling (PCE) strategy, with an estimated contribution of US$500 thousand. As indicated for subcomponent 1.1, the selection of BPs in subcomponent 1.2 will also prioritize quilombolas, Indigenous People, and traditional communities with differentiated scores and targeted calls for proposals for each group. Women will also be offered targeted calls .Subcomponent 1.3 – ATER for Agroecological Production (total estimated cost: US$ 8.38 million; US$ 7.15 million IBRD financing, and US$ 1.23 million counterpart financing). This subcomponent will finance: (i) the provision of Agricultural Technical Extension Services (ATER) to enable the design and implementation support of PFSPAs from subcomponent 1.1; (ii) the provision of ATER for the design and implementation support of BPs under subcomponent 1.2; and (iii) the training of ATER specialists of ATER entities. Under this subcomponent, ATER entities will organize the initial community diagnostic process and support CAs and POs in the development of their PFSPAs and BPs. This includes supporting CAs and POs in: (i) agreeing on their development goal for their Plan; (ii) identifying clear marketing goals and strategies, and (iii) identifying the material investments and knowledge needed to strengthen the production systems and implementing their Plans. Once the PFSPA or BP is approved, ATER entities will support CAs and POs in its implementation through any (or all) of the following activities according to the organizational capacity assessment of each CA and PO: (i) fiduciary aspects (including procurement and contracting); (ii) Technical Assistance for general management, governance and administration; (iii) technical assistance on technical , environmental and social risks and knowledge of Plan implementation; (iv) facilitate CAs and POs and their members to access additional sources of financing , services providers, as well as public food purchasing programs (PNAE, PAA) and to create opportunities for integration into value chains; (v) monitor the progress and quality of the Plan's implementation; and (vi) support to share experiences across CAs. ATER services provided under this subcomponent will be detailed in each PFSPA and BP and will be tailored to the organizational capacity of the supported CAs and POs (e.g less structured CAs may benefit from capacity-building in governance and management). The subcomponent will implement training events for ATER entities to enhance their skills and qualifications . Financing under this subcomponent is intended to support investments that improve climate change resilience and mitigation . Component 2 – Enhancing Environmental Practices (total estimated cost: US$ 13.86 million; US$ 11.11 million IBRD financing, and US$ 2.75 million from counterpart financing). This component will support environmental management, by promoting conservation and restoration initiatives, as well as sustainable practices . The activities implemented by the component should contribute to combating degradation and desertification that affects several regions of the state and to mitigating greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. Component 2 will seek to serve family farmers, including Indigenous People and quilombola communities, land reform settlements and women's agroecological networks. The component is linked to Pillar 2 of the MPA as it will strengthen public goods and services on agricultural and environmental innovation that will lead to farmland under environmentally sustainable management practices.Subcomponent 2.1 – Environmental protection and restoration initiatives (total estimated cost US$ 11.15 million; US$ 8.94 million IBRD financing, and US$ 2.21 million counterpart financing). This subcomponent will finance the preparation and implementation of: (i) Community Environmental Management Plans (CEMPs) benefiting family farmers through Community Associations (CAs), designed to support initiatives for the protect

Project Name: AM Pro-Sustainability - Fiscal, economic, social and environmental sustainability program of the State of Amazonas
Project Development Objective: Strengthen environmental regulatory framework, enhance fiscal sustainability, and mobilize finance for natural resource conservation and bioeconomy of the State of Amazonas.
Implementing Agency: Amazonas State Secretariat of Environment

Project Name: Integrated Agricultural Climate Resilient Service Delivery and Livelihoods
Project Development Objective: To improve access to climate resilient basic services and livelihoods opportunities in the targeted areas
Implementing Agency: Ministry of Agriculture, Environment and Fisheries
Abstract: The proposed project is an Investment Project Financing (IPF) with an IDA grant of US$50 million to be implemented over 5-years in Cabo Delgado Province. The project responds to addressing numerous challenges that exist in the Northern Mozambique, particularly Cabo Delgado Province, which include: (i) high and increasing poverty rates, with Nampula and Cabo Delgado Province as the highest, 81 percent and 78 percent respectively, (ii) high food and nutrition insecurity, with stunting rates above 40 percent, (iii) inadequate delivery of basic public service, (iv) high and recurrent climate shocks, and (iv) social tension and conflict, with broken social contracts. The project objective aims to improve access to climate resilient basic services and livelihoods opportunities. The project will holistically strengthen the capacity of districts to effectively deliver service in a climate and demand driven and inclusive manner, while improving sustainable livelihoods, and economic activities. The project, intervening in a deteriorated social fabric, will adopt a comprehensive multifaceted social inclusion and cohesion approach through: (i) mainstreaming participatory approaches to identify communities’ needs and priorities and enhance their voice and agency to improve climate resilient infrastructure investments; (ii) adopting community-based approaches to bring communities together and reduce existing tensions over limited resources and assets; (iii) mobilizing and empowering the youth with improved skills and economic opportunities, and (iv) mobilizing farmers to improving agricultural livelihoods and productivity, with specific attention towards the vulnerable women and youth. This comprehensive approach will help address the key drivers of conflict and fragility in Cabo Delgado Province.

Project Name: Uganda Strengthening Public Investment and Asset Management for Growth and Resilience Operation (PIM PLUS)
Project Development Objective: To strengthen the GoU's efficiency, accountability, and sustainability of public investment and asset management.
Implementing Agency: Ministry of Finance, Planning & Economic Development,National Planning Authority
Abstract: The program aims at strengthening the GoU's efficiency, accountability, and sustainability of public investment and asset management. Progress towards the achievement of the PDO will be measured through the following indicators: (a) Share of PIP projects, included since FY2026/27 and having undergone the PIM process, which are progressing on time, (b) Share of PIP projects, included since FY2026/27, for which progress reports about financial and physical progress are publicly available on an annual basis, (c) Increase in the share of assets in selected sectors that are recorded, monitored, and maintained and, (d) Increase funding for climate resilience of infrastructure assets. The operation will include an IPF component and a PforR component. The IPF component will consist of US$36 million, contributing to the Project Preparation Facility (PPF) hosted by the NPA or its successor; and US$4 million dedicated to institutional strengthening and change management, to be provided to the participating beneficiary institutions. The PPF will serve to demonstrate good practice in project preparation. Prioritization criteria for the PPF are: (i) projects already having completed the profile stage of the DC; (ii) strategic studies to inform the 10-fold strategy and NDP core projects, (iii) preparation of public investment projects enhancing Uganda’s mitigation or adaptation goals (e.g., irrigation and other water management, resilient infrastructure, urban public transport); and (iv) ensuring high-quality and timely environmental and social assessments. The institutional development and change management component will be flexible and based on priorities approved in annual workplans. The sub-component will support capacity strengthening for achieving DLIs/DLRs and the overall objectives of the operation.Current identified activities to be supported by the PPF include conducting feasibility and pre-feasibility studies. Proposed activities and sites for feasibility studies include; Kampala-Bombo Expressway – PPP, Kampala Outer Beltway, Kibuye- Busega Expressway study update, Kampala-Hoima Expressway, Water Supply and Sanitation Program Phase IlI, WASH Infrastructure Development in Lagging Communities - Islands and Fish Landing Sites, Integrated Flood and Drought Management Project, Entebbe Regional Referral Hospitals Infrastructure Development Project, Construction of Phase 2 o4RAf the Molecular Imaging and Therapy Centre(Levels 1 & 2), the Isotope production facility for the Uganda Cancer Institute and Support to PIM Centre of Excellence. Identified activities for pre-feasibility studies include Lopei Multi-purpose dam and Irrigation Development Project, Waste Management Project for Cities, Development of tourist infrastructure at 3 equator points in Kayabwe, NFO Island, Kayinja Ntara, Kikorongo and Ntuusi, Customized Tourism Tour of Kampala City and UWEC Infrastructure Development Project. The PforR component is substantial as it will support the PFMRS 2025-2030 and the associated Resource Enhancement and Accountability Program (REAP) II, which serves to implement the PFMRS.

Project Name: Rwanda: Wildlife Conservation Bond
Project Development Objective: Restore ecosystems and protect endangered chimpanzee populations in target conservation areas in Rwanda.
Implementing Agency: African Parks,Rwanda Development Board
Abstract: Disclaimer: THE FOLLOWING IS A SUMMARY OF A PROJECT WHICH IS SUBJECT TO COMPLETION AND AMENDMENT. IT IS NOT AN OFFER OR INVITATION TO SELL THE NOTES OR A SOLICITATION OF AN OFFER TO BUY THE NOTES, NOR DOES IT CONSTITUTE ANY FORM OF ADVICE. THIS SUMMARY IS SEPARATE FROM, AND SHOULD NOT BE READ IN COMBINATION WITH, ANY OFFER OR SALE OF THE NOTES, WHICH WILL BE MADE IN COMPLIANCE WITH APPLICABLE LAWS AND UNDER ENTIRELY SEPARATE LEGAL DOCUMENTATION AND OFFERING MATERIALS AT THE TIME OF OFFER. POTENTIAL INVESTORS SHOULD NOT SUBSCRIBE FOR ANY NOTES REFERRED TO IN THIS SUMMARY EXCEPT ON THE BASIS OF INFORMATION CONTAINED IN SUCH ENTIRELY SEPARATE LEGAL DOCUMENTATION AND OFFERING MATERIALS AT THE TIME OF OFFER. THIS SUMMARY IS VERY HIGH LEVEL FOR SIMPLICITY AND LEAVES OUT MATERIAL INFORMATION AND DOES NOT INLCUDE ANY LEGAL DOCUMENTATION THAT WOULD GOVERN THE NOTES.The Rwanda WCB will pilot a new financial instrument in an IDA country that passes project risk to capital market investors; a significant demonstration for financing public goods globally, allowing donors to pay only for successful outcomes. It links investment returns to a Key Performance Indicators (KPI) for ecosystem restoration (trees restored which protects endangered Eastern Chimpanzee habitat). The KPI will trigger a partial/full conservation success payment based on the level of achievement of the project's tree restoration efforts. Target landscapes include two of Rwanda's four national parks (Nyungwe National Park - the largest tract of forest in Rwanda and one of Africa's biodiversity hotspots) and the Gishwati-Mukura National Park - a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve) and buffer zones. The project development objective is to restore ecosystems and protect endangered chimpanzee populations in target conservation areas in Rwanda. The project will improve degraded areas, protect wildlife habitats, generate jobs, and strengthen resilience through ecosystem restoration with enhanced conservation area management and benefit local communities. The project will support an evidence-based and adaptive management approach that uses data-supported interventions to dynamically respond to changes in performance risks. It will invest in conservation of biodiversity and enhancement of conservation area resilience (component 1), promote sustainable landscapes and nature-based resilience (component 2), and project management and M&E support (component 3) – MRV paid by WCB foregone coupons) to execute project activities effectively and efficiently, including the ESF.

Project Name: Strengthening Coastal Resilience and the Economy Project
Project Development Objective: To increase coastal protection and conservation, enhance livelihood benefits, and reduce marine plastic pollution in targeted coastal communities.
Implementing Agency: State of Karnataka,State of Tamil Nadu
Abstract: The SHORE MPA program will support India’s vision for Integrated Coastal Zone Management while ensuring that the coastal zone's environment, landscapes, and natural values are in harmony with economic development. This will be done through convergence between federal and state governments based on their coastal priorities. Many coastal issues – particularly those related to local adaptation capacity, water resources, and infrastructure management – have regional dimensions, especially given the geographic and economic interconnectedness of coastal States. Under Phase-1 of the SHORE MPA, the coastal States of Karnataka and Tamil Nadu will be supported through shared learning and developing cost-effective solutions to build resilience to natural disasters and climate change. The project will provide positive environment benefits and will minimize exposure of people and economic assets to potential damage due to the effects of climate, through integrated planning and promotion of community driven nature-based solutions. The PDO will be achieved through four components that focus on: (i) stronger local institutions for integrated management of coastal zones; (ii) resilient shorelines through long-term planning and measures for protection of physical and natural assets and biodiversity conservation; (iii) resilient communities through income diversification, jobs and improved livelihood opportunities, specifically for vulnerable groups including women; and iv) healthier coastal ecosystems through measures for reducing plastic pollution and promoting circularity. The project primarily involves the following four categories of interventions: i) soft nature-based interventions for coastal erosion management, e.g mangrove afforestation, bio shields, sea grass, shelter belts, ecotourism measures such as board walks, blue flag beaches; ii) small scale works that e.g. Turtle and Dugong conservation centres, erosion management in one small island; prevention of ocean bound plastic pollution though establishment of trash barriers, traps and nets, small scale plastic collection/ segregation centres and material recovery facilities; iii) Goods primarily involving procurement e.g. equipment such as boats, water quality monitoring equipment, cameras, drones, etc.; iv) awareness initiatives, such as signages, sensitization programmes through SHGs (Plastic Mitras), festivals, etc., and; v) services involving various consultancies e.g. study on plastic pollution abatement, carbon finance approaches, etc.

Project Name: Kenya Watershed Services Improvement Project
Project Development Objective: The Project Development Objective (PDO) is to expand the area under sustainable watershed and landscape management for livelihoods and conservation in the project areas.
Implementing Agency: State Department of Forestry
Abstract: The KEWASIP will support a subset of activities contained in The National Landscape and Ecosystems Restoration Programme Strategy. Under the KEWASIP the selected activities are expected to be grouped under three Results Areas: (i) strengthened watershed planning, governance, and monitoring; (ii) watershed services and landscape restoration (private/communal lands); (iii) Public land management and restoration (public/protected lands).

Project Name: Ecuador Disaster Risk Management Development Policy Financing with a Cat-DDO
Project Development Objective: To strengthen the Government of Ecuador’s program to manage risks resulting from climate, disaster, and public health shocks by (i) enhancing institutional capacity and (ii) mainstreaming resilience and climate adaptation in selected sectors.
Implementing Agency: The Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF)

Project Name: Costa Rica Fiscal Management and Green Growth
Project Development Objective: The proposed DPL supports the Government of Costa Rica’s efforts to (i) enhance the efficiency of fiscal management; and (ii) support the transition to a green and climate resilient economy.
Implementing Agency: Ministerio de Hacienda

Region: Middle East, North Africa, Afghanistan, and Pakistan
Project Name: Support for improved farm management and piloting models of aggregation in Iraq
Project Development Objective: The PDO aims to deliver proof of concept for an innovative aggregation model to enhance productivity, commercialization, and climate resilience in the dairy supply chain in selected regions of Iraq.
Implementing Agency: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Borrower: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Abstract: The project aims to pilot innovative commercialization models and extract lessons by investing in five interrelated areas: (i) promoting strategic productive alliances between smallholders and private sector, (ii) increasing access to productive assets and technology, and (iii) promoting more effective and climate-smart practices for feed and livestock production; (iv) building business development skills and improving knowledge about climate-smart agriculture; and (v) sharing the results with decision makers. The targeted species are cattle, buffalo, goats and sheep. These value chains are considered strategic for both food security/nutritional supply and for their comparative advantage on the national markets and associated income generation potential. Furthermore, the project will strengthen the government’s organizational capacity at the governorates level to ensure the sustainability of the intervention and contribute to scaling up.

Project Name: Rio Grande do Norte: Sustainable Development and Governance Project
Project Development Objective: To enhance market access, transport infrastructure, and the climate resilience of family farmers in selected areas of Rio Grande do Norte.
Implementing Agency: Governo Cidadão
Borrower: Secretariat of Planning - Rio Grande do Norte
Abstract: Rio Grande do Norte has a population of 3.3 million people (1.7 percent of Brazil’s total population) and a monthly household income of $R 1,267 – compared to the Brazil’s average of $R 1,625, while its poverty rate is 46.2 percent. Afro-descendants correspond to 57 percent of the State population - and they account for most of the economically vulnerable population. The GDP of Rio Grande do Norte corresponds to approximately 1 percent of Brazil’s national GDP. Rio Grande do Norte covers an area of 52,810km² (815.53 km² urbanized), and is the third smallest compared to the nine states in the Northeast region, Brazil's poorest. Most of the state (93 percent) lies within the Sertão, the semi-arid region of the NEB which is disproportionately prone to climate change effects. Road transport is key for Rio Grande do Norte logistics, but the sustainability of its assets is at risk due to poor maintenance and safety and climate resilience challenges. RN is traversed by 1,480 kilometers (km) of federal roadways and 4,540 km of state roads—of which 3,464 are paved, which are key for State logistics. The first phase of the Project (P126452) has implemented 274 km of State roads, but due to a lack of resources, the state still has significant physical bottlenecks in its road system – 24,3 percent of the State Road network is in bad condition, and 40.2 percent in regular – showcasing its challenges to maintain the road network, with no experience in implementing performance-based contracts (PBCs). Additionally, low capacity in the Government to act towards climate resilience compounds the emergency costs for roads in rainy years such as 2023-2024. RN roads continue to lack adequate safe road designs – especially in urban settlements – and maintenance of road infrastructure. According to data from the Ministry of Health, between 2019 and 2021, road traffic fatalities have remained stable in RN, with 392 traffic-related deaths in 2022 (11.9 fatalities per 100k inhabitants). While agricultural production in RN only contributes 3.4 percent to the state’s overall GDP, it is still a driving force in the labor market, accounting for one-third of the state’s labor force. Moreover, there is an urgent need for an upgrade in farm-to-market infrastructure to ensure better commercial access, particularly around the key production centers. According to the 2017 Census, there were 50,680 family farms, representing 80 percent of the 63,350 farms statewide. Past surveys showed less than two percent of family farmers were members of agricultural cooperatives, 23 percent were members of associations, 46 percent were affiliated with the Rural Workers Unions (STRs), and almost 30 percent did not engage in any kind of collective organization. Cooperatives of family farmers face difficulties with obtaining Federal Government Food Safety certification (SIF/MAPA), a significant barrier for accessing markets. Whilst these barriers are being slowly overcome, rural market access is impeded during the wet season when roads become impassable. As experience from the previous project shows, better-quality road pavement leads to agricultural sales increase, as this has been clearly demonstrated by the milk and fruit sectors.Tourism activity accounts for 8 percent of Rio Grande do Norte’s GDP and contributes to over 100 thousand formal jobs. Between 2002 and 2020, the share of value added from services to the state’s economy – tourism included – grew from 66 percent to 77 percent. However, when the COVID-19 pandemic hit, the State lost a significant number of incoming international flights which are yet to resume, reducing foreign currency income. Tourism in the state continues to suffer from a lack of diversification; over 90 percent of visitors during peak seasons visit or plan to visit beaches – benefitting larger companies rather than community-based tourism, while only 14 percent visit or plan to visit inland cities. The proposed Project aims at developing the agriculture and tourism sectors of five key hubs for the economy of the state, while improving transport access with a safer, climate resilient, and sustainable road asset management strategy. Those five hubs have been selected based on the findings of a study commissioned by the state during implementation of Phase 1, which considered, inter alia: volumes of farm credit for capital expenditures and fixed costs; federal fiscal incentives and state fiscal incentives for industrial development given since 2003, linkages with road infrastructure, presence of traditional communities and rural settlements, and market sales potential, including for exports. The five hubs are: (i) Costa Branca region, where there is cluster of fruit cooperatives, (ii) Sertão region, where there is a cluster of cotton cooperatives; (iii) Serido region, where cheese production by women groups (cheese making/queijeiras) predominate, (iv) “Rota do Frio”, where honey production is being developed, and (v) Costa Mar, where animal protein is the key livestock/agricultural output. In doing so, the project will invest in family farming resilience (climate adaptation/mitigation, productivity, and marketing of products) and in an enabling a better business environment for the cooperatives and tourism organizations in these regions to flourish. Crucially, there will be a significant investment in safe and resilient access to road infrastructure to ensure full access to markets and complement the sector-specific interventions.COMPONENT 1 – Access to markets and improved climate resilience of family farmersSub-component 1.1 - Linking family farmers to markets Sub-component 1.2 - Strengthening family farming institutions and systemsSub-component 1.3 - Strengthening the enabling environment for family farming and sustainable community-based tourism market development COMPONENT 2 – Improving sustainable, safe, and resilient access to transport in RNSub-component 2.1: Proactive maintenance CREMA-DBM: Long-term performance-based safe and resilient road management contracts for state road corridorsSub-component 2.2 -State Infrastructure improvement using Public-Private PartnershipsSub-component 2.3 Institutional strengthening, covering three sets of activities: proactive, safe, and resilient road asset management; green mobility and logistics; and social inclusion and genderCOMPONENT 3 - Project Management and Institutional Strengthening

Project Name: Colombia Sustainable Development of Family Farming
Project Development Objective:
The Program Development Objectives (PrDO) is to enhance agriculture income and resilience to climate change of family farmers in selected rural areas.
 

 The Project Development Objective (PDO) is to increase market access and strengthen resilience to climate risks of family farmers in selected regions of Colombia. In case of an Eligible Crisis or Emergency, respond promptly and effectively to it.
Implementing Agency: Ministerio de Agricultura y Desarrollo Rural
Abstract: Phase 1 of the project focuses on the Caribbean Region of Colombia, Santander, and Antioquia (CRCS&A), covering the departments of La Guajira, Cesar, Magdalena, Bolivar, Sucre, Atlantico, Cordoba, Santander, and Antioquia. This region is home to 18 million people, including 5.8 million in rural areas, and contains 1.2 million family farms, accounting for 52% of Colombia’s total. The project prioritizes five geographic clusters identified for agrarian reform while extending benefits to other areas, reaching 205,000 beneficiaries, including 186,000 direct beneficiaries and 19,300 indirect beneficiaries, representing approximately 52,000 rural households. Beneficiaries include family farmers and their producer organizations (POs), such as cooperatives and community associations engaged in agriculture, livestock, forestry, and aquaculture, with representation from indigenous peoples, Afro-descendants, and Raizal communities. The project is estimated to cost USD 268.8 million, funded by USD 250 million from IBRD, USD 8 million from the Food System 2030 grant, USD 1.7 million from the Korean-World Bank Partnership Facility, and USD 9.1 million in co-financing from POs. The project includes six components. Component 1: Accelerating the Delivery of Agricultural Innovations includes subcomponents on scaling agricultural innovation for family farmers, enhancing the transfer of agricultural innovations, and institutional strengthening for agricultural innovation, led by AGROSAVIA. Component 2: Strengthening Agricultural Extension Services focuses on improving enabling conditions (including registries, the National Agricultural Extension Fund, and monitoring and evaluation) and delivering extension services to family farmers, led by ADR with support from MADR. Component 3: Agroindustry Development and Access to Markets includes subcomponents on pre-investment in sustainable agriculture businesses, implementing business plans, and strengthening market access, led by ADR. Component 4: Policy Analysis and Repurposing Support focuses on assessing, testing, and scaling innovative policies and coordinating the program’s learning agenda, led by MADR. Component 5: Contingency Emergency Response Component (CERC) is designed to address crises, disasters, and health emergencies, led by MADR and ADR. Component 6: Project Management and Coordination includes administrative activities, audits, and evaluations, managed through dedicated units in MADR, ADR, and AGROSAVIA.

Project Name: Maharashtra Project on Climate Resilient Agriculture Phase - II
Project Development Objective: The Project Development Objective (PDO) is to improve resilience and profitability of smallholder farmers across selected districts in Maharashtra.
Implementing Agency: Department of Agriculture
Abstract: Improve Resilience and promote sustainable agriculture with the following four pillars viz: Pillar 1 - Resource Efficient Productivity Enhancement; Pillar 2 - Promoting Precision Agriculture for Emissions Management; Pillar 3- Improving and Building Income Resilience; Pillar 4 - Lighthouse Approach for Strengthening Institutions. The details of these pillars will be discussed with the client and the task team, will be finalised during project preparation.

Project Name: Mexico BioCarbon Emission Reduction Program
Project Development Objective: The program will generate payments for measured, reported, and verified Emission Reductions (ER) from the Land Use, Land Use Change, and Forestry (LULUCF) sector in the jurisdiction and will distribute ER payments in accordance with an agreed benefit sharing plan.
Implementing Agency: CONAFOR
Abstract: The proposed Mexico Emission Reductions Program (Mexico’s ERP) is led by the GoM with the goal of generating verified ISFL ER and distribute ER payments in accordance with an agreed benefit sharing plan. Mexico’s ERP will be implemented across four northern states Chihuahua, Coahuila, Durango, and Nuevo Leon. The selection of these states is based on their mitigation potential in the forestry and agricultural sectors, as well as their political commitment to integrated landscape management.For the GoM, this program represents an opportunity to scale up various interventions at the forest-landscape level to better address the main drivers of deforestation and degradation. The Program recognizes that deforestation and forest degradation are complex and multifactorial phenomena, especially considering that in Mexico forests are found in multiple land use landscapes and deforestation is not only determined by direct productive activities but also by underlying causes involving multiple stakeholders. Thus, the program seeks to: (i) strengthen intersectoral collaboration to better align investments in forest landscapes, (ii) reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from the land sector and improve forest livelihoods through the promotion of activities to conserve and sustainably use and restore forest landscapes, (iii) maintain and enhance Mexico’s capacity to monitor and report GHG emissions. By achieving the Program objectives, the GoM will enhance its capacity to access new sources of climate finance.Mexico’s Emissions Reduction Program will adopt a programmatic approach beginning with interventions in the LULUCF sector and aiming to transitioning a potential second phase to emissions reductions from the AFOLU sector. This ESRS focuses on the first phase. A potential second phase which would be prepared separately will require a stand alone E&S assessment depending on program activities under this second phase.The ERP is designed in two components: Component 1: Emission Reductions payment distributed in accordance with agreed Benefit Sharing Plan (BSP): Subcomponent 1.a.: Payment for ERCs and Subcomponent 1.b.: Distribution of Emission Reductions payments as per an agreed BSP. Component 2: Program’s Operating and Coordination Costs. Activities through this component will better target Program measures, maintain program operation, enhance GHG inventory data, improve interagency collaboration, and mainstream gender.The Program measures/activities that will generate the Emission Reductions will be financed by CONAFOR and implemented through its public incentive programs.

Project Name: Blueing the Caspian Sea: Building Capacities for Pollution Monitoring and Biodiversity Planning
Project Development Objective: The Project Development Objective is to strengthen pollution monitoring and biodiversity monitoring and planning in targeted sites within the Caspian Sea in Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, and Turkmenistan
Implementing Agency: United Nations Office for Project Services (UNOPS)
Abstract: About the GEF FinanceThe Global Environment Facility (GEF) is providing US$ 11,743,120 in grant financing to the World Bank and UNEP as GEF Implementing Agencies. The finance will benefit Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan. The WB will seek Board approval for a US$ 8,243,120 project for which United Nations Office for Project Services (UNOPS) will serve as the GEF Executing Agency. A GEF Project Preparation Grant (PPG) of US$183,489 will be awarded to UNOPS for the purposes of preparing the applicable ESF instruments, engagement of the three countries. The United Nations Environment Program (UNEP) will seek approval per their own procedures for GEF financing and will do internal execution of the grant with the Tehran Convention Interim Secretariat (TCIS).The WB has no fiduciary or supervision accountability for the UNEP-executed project. However, the WB is the implementing agency submitting the combined project to the GEF for CEO Endorsement. This co-implementation arrangement has been agreed between the World Bank and UNEP.The WB Project.The operation aims to assist countries in managing pollution and improve biodiversity conservation. This will be achieved by strengthening the capacity of the three participating countries, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, and Turkmenistan. The project complements ongoing efforts of countries to meet the obligation of the Tehran Convention and the associated protocols.Component 1. Pollution management strengthened (US$ 3,900,000). This component will finance technical assistance, workshops, and other capacity building measures to improve policy harmonization and regional cooperation on pollution management in the Caspian Sea. It will also seek to sharing knowledge among the countries exchanges between practitioners on best practices. The component will support activities needed for countries meet the obligations under the Moscow Protocol engages countries to implement measures to prevent, control, and minimize pollution from land-based sources affecting the Caspian Sea and its coastal areas. The capacity of national institutions related to pollution may also be supported by provision of equipment. The component may also finance the development of National Programs of Action (NPAs) and investment plans for pollution mitigation.Component 2. Protected areas management strengthened (US$ 3,900,000).This component will finance technical assistance, workshops, and other capacity building measures to improve policy harmonization and regional cooperation on biodiversity management in the Caspian Sea. It will also seek to sharing knowledge among the countries exchanges between practitioners on best practices. The component will support activities needed for countries meet the obligations under the Ashgabat Protocol that engages countries to protect, preserve, and restore the health and integrity of the biological diversity and the ecosystem of the Caspian Sea. The component will support the improvement of specific protected areas in three participating countries, including expansion of the protected areas and management within the territorial waters of the three countries including enhancement of existing, and development of new PA management plans, workshops, training, and implementation of management plans. The component will also finance national public awareness programs on biodiversity loss in the Caspian Sea.Component 3. Project Management (US$ 443,120). This component will support the technical implementation of the project activities, including FM and procurement, overall monitoring of project results, production of progress reports, and Environmental and Social Framework (ESF) compliance, with the establishment of a culturally appropriate grievance redress mechanism. The UNOPS Blueing the Caspian Sea Project Implementation Unit (PIU) will be housed in appropriate facilities, preferable in the region and will be composed of professional, administrative, and support staff. The UNOPS BCS PIU will be responsible for the overall coordination of the WB project and will, among others, (a) oversee the preparation of annual operating plans and (b) prepare progress and other reports, as required by the GEF and the World Bank.

Project Name: Productive Social Safety Net III
Project Development Objective: To enhance income-generating opportunities of PSSN beneficiaries and build adaptive SP delivery systems.
Implementing Agency: Tanzania Social Action Fund
Abstract: The PSSN 3 Project will continue to support Tanzania’s flagship safety net program, providing targeted assistance to extreme poor and vulnerable households with the objective to enhance the income-generating opportunities and human capital of beneficiaries. The project will deliver integrated interventions designed to: (i) stabilize income to promote and protect human capital, (ii) encourage savings and facilitate the transition to improved livelihoods, (iii) boost productivity and income-generating capabilities, and (iv) build resilience against shocks and the long-term impacts of climate change. The project will continue to support PSSN core activities: cash transfers, economic inclusion, and public works. The productive cash transfer program will remain central, emphasizing human capital development. It will be complemented with livelihood and economic inclusion activities that aim to increase household income through asset accumulation, better risk management, and a shift toward more productive, climate-smart employment. Additionally, the climate-smart public works program will offer safety nets during the lean season, mitigating food shortages through sub-projects that generate community assets and contribute to local climate change adaptation and mitigation strategies. The project will also support the PSSN’s evolution to an Adaptive Social Protection (ASP) model. To do so, the project will invest in digital and dynamic delivery systems, including expanding and refining the TASAF social registry with the long-term goal of evolving it into a national unified social registry. These systems will enable more efficient and effective responses to the needs of vulnerable populations, which could facilitate targeted interventions across sectors like education, health, and disaster response.

Project Name: Productive Safety Net Program 6
Project Development Objective: The project development objective is to enhance jobs and livelihoods creation and access to human capital services for poor and vulnerable households, and strengthen the adaptability of the social protection system.
Implementing Agency: Ministry of Agriculture
Abstract: PSNP 6 will be transformative with a focus on building resilience through jobs and livelihoods creation enhancing the productivity of rural Ethiopians living in poverty. The project will also focus on improving human capital outcomes of beneficiaries and their households, as well as enhancing an Adaptive Social Protection system to ensure adaptability and flexibility in responding to shocks. Ultimately, this project will contribute towards reducing rural poverty in Ethiopia.

Project Name: Accelerating Innovation and Catalyzing Capacity for Resilience in Africa
Project Development Objective: To scale agrifood innovation and enhance scaling capacities of African organizations and stakeholders in Africa.
Implementing Agency: International Centre of Insect Physiology and Ecology
Borrower: International Centre of Insect Physiology and Ecology
Abstract: The Project will have five main components:1. Enhancing data systems and decision-making tools 2. Strengthening regional scaling capacity 3. Scaling-up innovation uptake4. Boosting skills for innovation and jobs 5. Project management

Project Name: Poultry and Aquaculture Development Project
Project Development Objective: To improve cost-effectiveness, market access and resilience of target poultry and aquaculture value chains in Congo.
Implementing Agency: Ministry of Agriculture Livestock and Fisheries
Borrower: Ministry of Planning, Statistics and Regional Integration
Abstract: The project will finance the following activities to realize its development objective:Component 1: Enhancing Access to High-Quality and Affordable Inputs Component 2: Facilitating Production and MarketingComponent 3: Strengthening the Agribusiness Ecosystem Component 4: Contingency Emergency ResponseComponent 5: Project Management

Project Name: Sustainable Congo Basin Forest Economies
Project Development Objective: To improve forest management, strengthen forest value chains, and generate jobs in targeted areas in Congo Basin Forest countries.
Implementing Agency: Central Africa Forest Commission (COMIFAC),Central Africa Economic and Monetary Union
Abstract: This horizontal MPA - The Sustainable Congo Basin Forest Economies (SCBFE) Program is an ambitious commitment to create jobs and economic opportunities through sustainable management of Congo Basin Forests (CBF). It will operationalize the Global Challenge Program - Forests for development, climate and biodiversity by focusing on sustainably developing value-added products and services from the forest sector, increasing jobs and improving regional cooperation and national capacity for biodiversity conservation. The proposed program responds to the World Bank Group’s 3-pillar approach to job creation: (i) strengthening governance and policies; (ii) establishing the foundational infrastructure for forest jobs; and (iii) mobilizing private capital to deliver solutions at scale. It leverages globally tested approaches for sustainable management of forests, including strengthening value chains that deliver jobs and economic opportunities to reduce poverty, while promoting the rich biodiversity of the forests. At the regional level, the project will enhance climate benefits and help countries coordinate their climate and forest policies for greater development impact.

Project Name: Montenegro Forest for Shared Prosperity
Project Development Objective: The Project Development Objective (PDO) is to improve the sustainable management of forest resources and to enhance the competitiveness of the forest industry in targeted project areas in Montenegro.
Implementing Agency: Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Management
Abstract: The proposed project interventions will focus on improving the bioeconomy of Montenegro through the strengthening of competitiveness of the forest industry and forest fire management including improvement of the enabling policy and institutional environment. On the one hand it aims at ensuring the sustainability of the supply chain of forest products through sustainable forest management to enhance economic benefits, ecosystem services and carbon sequestration. This includes integrating environmental, economic and social responsible principles and benchmarks into the supply chain management of the forest products. This entails the standardization and certification of forest products to ensure the quality of forest management and production, increasing transparency to curb illegal logging, intensifying forest fire protection, and modernizing forest management system. On the other hand, the proposed project focuses on improving the competitiveness of the forest industry in Montenegro to enhance economic benefits and carbon conservation. This includes support to addressing market challenges and developing wood-processing industry. Lastly, the proposed project will also support regulatory developments and institutional capacity building to ensure responsible forest resource management, enhancing informed forest management decisions, improve value-added production, and ensure compliance with international sustainability standards while contributing to the country's economic growth and environmental protection. The proposed project’s design consists of four components: Component 1: Institutional Capacity Development and System Modernization; Component 2: Enhancing Climate Resilience and Information Services; Component 3: Improving the Competitiveness of the Forest Industry; and Component 4: Project Management, Monitoring and Communication. Component 1. Institutional Capacity Development and System Modernization. The objective of this component is to improve the enabling conditions for a stronger Montenegro forest industry and improved the supply chain of forest products to spur economic growth and shared prosperity. The component will facilitate the development of a favorable regulatory environment as well as removal of constraints for forest industry growth and management. The component will focus on the following core interventions: improving policy environment, institutional capacity development, system modernization, and supporting government’s reform of the forest governance including the effective implementation of the new Forest Law. Component 2. Enhancing Climate Resilience and Information Services. The objective of this component of the project is to enhance climate resilience of the forest resources through prevention of forest fires, ensuring the sustainable supply of raw materials to the forest industry, improving informed forest management decisions, and improving the measurement of carbon stocks. The component focuses on the quantification of forest resources and carbon stocks, fair and efficient timber allocation, reducing the risk of wildfires, and restoring degraded forest lands. Component 3. Improving the Competitiveness of Forest Industry. The objective of this component will be to increase the economic contributions of the forest industry to the national development of Montenegro through expanding access to finance, correcting inefficient manufacturing practices, boosting product diversifications, increasing processing capacity, production of profitable high-value wood products, and creation of more high-paying jobs. Component 4. Project Management, Monitoring, and Communication. This component will finance the operating costs of the Project Implementation Unit (PIU) to carry out the oversight and management functions of the project. This includes activities such as procurement and contract management, financial management, environmental and social risk management, monitoring and evaluation (M&E), stakeholder engagement and communication as well as documentation of lessons learned from project implementation and stakeholders’ efforts to scale-up good practices.

Project Name: Nigeria Sustainable Agricultural Value-Chains for Growth
Project Development Objective: To foster sustainable growth and job creation across selected agricultural value chains in Nigeria.
Implementing Agency: Federal Ministry of Agriculture and Food Security and Selected States
Abstract: The proposed project aims to address the critical challenges that affect competitiveness and resilience of agricultural value-chains, and thus stifle the prospects for value-added growth and job creation. In summary these key challenges include: (i) low institutional capacity and non-conducive policies that affect private sector (including farmers') participation in key value-chains; (ii) structural constraints that affect sector modernization and productivity and thus stifle private sector and farmers' returns and quality of jobs from agricultural value-chains; and (iii) poor integration of farmers to markets. The proposed project will therefore focus on interventions that directly or indirectly contribute towards Nigeria's agricultural sector modernization, productivity and value-added growth, including improved food and nutrition security in line with the country's Agriculture Promotion Policy (APP), National Agricultural Technology and Innovation Policy (NATIP). Nigeria's priorities as highlighted in these policy documents is to achieve self-sufficiency in key commodities, transform agriculture into a business-oriented sector, and ensure food security, while also promoting sustainable income and job growth. This operation will also be aligned to the Bank's Country Partnership Framework (CPF) as well as the recent aspirations highlighted in the Global Food and Nutrition Security (FNS) Program and the Mission Agri-connect.

Project Name: SAHEL RESILAND CHAD: Building Resilience through Sustainable Natural Resource Management
Project Development Objective: To improve adoption of climate resilient landscape management methods and access to livelihood restoration activities in targeted communities
Implementing Agency: Ministry of Environment, Fisheries and Sustainable Development
Borrower: Ministry of Finance, Budget, Economy and Plan
Abstract: The project aims to strengthen the resilience of vulnerable rural populations in the face of climate change, including the fight against land degradation and desertification, and to support the integrated and inclusive management of natural resources and land, including increased availability of water resources to support livelihoods. The project will support the development of low-carbon, nature-positive, value chains from non-timber forest products (NTFP) for vulnerable populations, particularly women and young people in the Great Green Wall intervention zone. Value chains such as gum arabic, balanites, and forage crops, will be part of nature based solutions to improve resilience to climate variability, restore degraded lands and improve economic resilience of vulnerable populations. Investments will include planting native and drought-resistant trees and crops, forest conservation, assisted natural regeneration, agroforestry, land restoration, adequate management of surface water (stabilization of dunes, stone lines, hedges, water catchments), reforestation with local and non-invasive species. The project will invest in improving knowledge and management of water resources, essential for maintaining livelihood activities, and will include water retention weirs and underground water harvesting practices.

Project Name: Development, Resilience and Valorization of Transboundary Water for West Africa - DREVE
Project Development Objective: To improve the management, valorization and climate resilience of surface and ground water resources, and strengthen transboundary water cooperation for West Africa.
Implementing Agency: Permanent Interstate Committee for drought control in the Sahel - CILSS,Senegal River Basin Development Organization - OMVS
Borrower: Mali,Burkina Faso,Guinea,Niger Basin Authority - NBA,West African Economic and Monetary Union (WAEMU),Senegal,Mauritania
Abstract: The proposed Development, Resilience & Valuation of Water for West Africa Program (DREVE) aims at strengthening cooperation for development and resilience by promoting transboundary water resources as a catalyst for prosperity and cooperation in West Africa. The Program will be implemented through a combination of water management and development activities to support economic development, food security and resilience to climate change in the sub-region.The first phase of the Program is structured around the four following Pillars:Pillar 1) on Transboundary Surface Water Resources Development, Resilience and Valuation to strengthen River Basin Organizations (RBOs) in West Africa and support rehabilitation and investments on priority regional infrastructures. In Phase 1, this pillar will primarily support the Senegal River Development Organization (OMVS) and member countries in (i) scaling-up protection and restoration of watershed and water quality, (ii) strengthening skills and good practices for dam safety, (iii) improving the Diama dam and related structures (rehabilitation and extension of flood protecting dikes) to secure assets and water supply, (iv) preparing studies for future water storage and renewable energy development, (v) developing studies for the future development and management of navigation the Senegal River from Senegal to Mali. For navigation, early works may include rehabilitation of priority ports of call in the OMVS Navigation project, support for dredging in the navigable channel and starting works on priority roads for SITRAM (OMVS' Multimodal Transport Integrated System). This Pillar will also provide Technical Assistance to the Niger Basin Authority (NBA) in planning for the development of infrastructure and navigation, including updating the Master Plan for Water Development and Management in the Niger Basin.Pillar 2) Groundwater for development and resilience aims at providing resilient high-quality infrastructure for tapping into sustainable groundwater resources and to improve associated stakeholder capacity. Groundwater development will support three areas: (i) irrigated agriculture to expand shallow-groundwater irrigation; (ii) drinking water supply to develop durable groundwater infrastructure for potable use, and (iii) pastoralism development to enhance water availability for pastoralists through groundwater-fed watering points.Pillar 3) Leveraging Transboundary Water for Irrigation and Food Security aims at ensuring the coordinated development of irrigation tapping into and benefiting from transboundary water resources. Irrigation and agricultural investments will target development of more than 50,000 ha based on the studies prepared under the Sahel Irrigation Initiative Support Project (SIIP - P154482) and ready for implementation. During phase 1, an additional 40,000 ha will be further studied for construction work during phase 2. The project will also support farmers in financing agricultural value chain development to ensure the valuation and sustainability of irrigation schemes.Pillar 4) Strengthening regional Water Security and Climate Resilience to establish a regional platform and facility for the coordinated development, monitoring and resilience of water resources. The platform will support the development of storage, drought and flood management plans and of studies for dam/storage rehabilitation or development for numerous productive use (inc. hydropower). This pillar will also gather expertise and knowledge (including in dam safety) as well as strengthen early warning systems at regional level.A Contingent Emergency Response Component (CERC) will be included in the project.
